newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan overseas investment down 50 pct in Jan-Mar.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan overseas investment down 50 pct in Jan-Mar.

text.p: Taiwan's overseas investment, excluding that in mainland China, fell 50 percent between January and March to US$360.554 million from the same period in 1996, the Investment Commision said on Tuesday.
Investment in "other" unspecified regions totalled $214.468 million, followed by investment in the United States which rose 12 percent to $50.185 million.
The government's "south-bound" policy received a boost, with more Taiwan businesses investing in Southeast Asia.
Worried that its businessmen could become too dependent on China, Taiwan launched the policy in late 1993 to promote investment in Southeast Asia instead of the mainland.
Investment in Vietnam jumped 73 percent to $37.686 million, followed by investment in Indonesia, which leapt sharply from only $105,000 to $22.857 million.

Basic metal and metal manufacturing industries topped the list of Taiwan companies investing overseas, with a total of $75.917 million, followed by international trade with $75.645 million and financial and insurance industries with $52.964 million.
The commission approved a total of US$275 million worth of Taiwanese indirect investment in China in 78 projects between January and March, up 7.44 percent from the same period a year ago.
Foreign investment in Taiwan rose 28 percent to US$426.649 million in the first three months of 1997 from the same period in 1996.
Investment from "other" unspecified regions increased 51 percent to $137.128 million, followed by investment from the United States, which was up 58 percent to $71.452 million.
European investment gained 50 percent to $41.683 million, while investment from Japan rose 16 percent to $21.750 million.
